components.text: % of population that plays sports regularly
components.explanation: Not everyone participates in sports regularly

components.text: Average annual sporting goods spending per athlete
components.explanation: This converts athletic participation into revenue
Pro teams don't determine consumer equipment spending
Athlete salaries don't affect equipment purchases

components.text: % of sports that are team vs individual
components.explanation: Sport type breakdown is too detailed
Attendance measures spectators, not participants
Facility costs don't drive equipment demand

explanation: To size the US sporting goods market, start with people who actively play sports rather than just watch, then multiply by their average annual spending on equipment and gear

prompt: What's the annual revenue of wedding services in the US?

components.explanation: This is your base for potential marriages

components.text: % of population that gets married annually
components.explanation: Marriage rates determine the total wedding market
This is total spending per wedding

components.text: % of budget spent on services vs goods
components.explanation: Services include planning, catering, photography vs goods
Venue count is supply-side, not demand measurement
Ring costs are goods, not services

components.text: % of weddings that are outdoor vs indoor
components.explanation: Venue type is too detailed for market sizing
Guest count affects budget but captured in total spending
Photography is one service, not the whole market

explanation: To estimate the US wedding services market, start with people getting married each year, multiply by average wedding budgets, then focus on the services portion of that spending

prompt: What's the size of the Canadian e-commerce market?

components.explanation: This is your potential online shopping base
Not everyone shops online regularly

components.text: Average annual online spending per shopper
components.explanation: This converts online shoppers into revenue
Physical stores serve different channels
Internet speed enables shopping but doesn't drive spending

components.text: % of purchases that are delivered vs pickup
components.explanation: Delivery method is operational, not market sizing
Shipping costs don't determine total spending
Website count doesn't measure consumer demand

explanation: To size Canada's e-commerce market, focus on people who actually shop online rather than in-store only, then multiply by their average annual online spending

prompt: What's the annual revenue of food trucks in the US?

components.explanation: This is your potential street food customer base

components.text: % of population that eats street food regularly
components.explanation: Not everyone eats street food regularly

components.text: % of street food purchases from trucks vs other vendors
components.explanation: Food trucks compete with carts, stalls, and stands

components.text: Average spending per food truck visit
components.explanation: This converts visits into actual spending

components.text: Average visits per person per month
components.explanation: Frequent customers drive most of the revenue
Restaurants serve a different market segment
Operating costs don't determine customer revenue

components.text: % of food trucks that serve lunch vs dinner
components.explanation: Meal timing breakdown is too granular
Preparation time doesn't affect customer spending
Permit count doesn't measure market demand

explanation: To estimate the US food truck market, start with regular street food consumers, identify what portion chooses trucks over other options, then multiply by visit frequency and spending

prompt: What's the size of the Mexican telecommunications market?

components.explanation: This is your potential mobile user base
Not everyone has mobile phone service

components.text: Average monthly mobile spending per user
components.explanation: This converts users into monthly revenue
Tower count is infrastructure, not consumer demand
Income affects spending ability but too indirect

components.text: % of plans that are prepaid vs postpaid
components.explanation: Plan type breakdown is too detailed
Call duration doesn't affect plan pricing
Company count doesn't determine market size

explanation: To size Mexico's telecom market, focus on people who actually have mobile service, then multiply by their average monthly spending on mobile plans and services

prompt: What's the annual revenue of home improvement stores in the US?

components.explanation: This is your potential DIY market
Renters typically don't do major improvements

components.text: % of homeowners who do DIY projects annually
components.explanation: Not all homeowners tackle DIY projects

components.text: Average annual spending on home improvement supplies
components.explanation: This converts DIY activity into retail spending
Contractors buy supplies but serve different market
Home age affects renovation need but too indirect

components.text: % of projects that are indoor vs outdoor
components.explanation: Project location breakdown is too detailed
Completion time doesn't affect supply spending
Store costs don't determine customer spending

explanation: To estimate US home improvement retail, focus on homeowners who do DIY projects rather than hire contractors, then multiply by their annual spending on supplies

prompt: What's the size of the US podcast advertising market?

components.explanation: This is your potential podcast audience

components.text: % of population that listens to podcasts regularly
components.explanation: Not everyone listens to podcasts regularly

components.text: Average podcast listening hours per listener per week
components.explanation: Heavy listeners drive most ad exposure

components.text: Average ad revenue per listening hour
components.explanation: This converts listening time into ad revenue
Podcast quantity doesn't determine ad spending
Episode length is captured in listening hours

components.text: % of listeners who use premium vs free services
components.explanation: Premium services often have fewer ads

components.text: Average number of ads per episode
components.explanation: Ad frequency is captured in revenue per hour
Production costs don't determine ad revenue

explanation: To size the US podcast ad market, start with regular podcast listeners, estimate their weekly listening hours, then multiply by advertising revenue generated per hour of listening

prompt: What's the annual revenue of spa and wellness services in Canada?

components.explanation: This is your potential wellness market

components.text: % of adults interested in wellness services
components.explanation: Interest in wellness doesn't always lead to spa visits

components.text: % of interested adults who actually use spa services
components.explanation: Many interested people never actually book services

components.text: Average annual spa spending per customer
components.explanation: This converts spa usage into revenue
Therapist count is supply-side, not demand
Treatment time doesn't affect annual spending

components.text: % of services that are massage vs facial vs other
components.explanation: Service type breakdown is too detailed
Facility size doesn't drive customer demand
Equipment costs don't determine customer spending

explanation: To estimate Canada's spa market, start with adults interested in wellness who actually use spa services rather than just thinking about it, then multiply by annual spending

prompt: What's the size of the US craft beer market?

components.explanation: This is your potential drinking population
Not all adults consume alcohol
Beer competes with wine and spirits

components.text: % of beer drinkers who choose craft over mass market
components.explanation: Craft beer competes with mass market brands

components.text: Average annual craft beer spending per craft drinker
components.explanation: This converts craft beer preference into revenue
Brewery count is supply-side, not consumer demand
Tax rates affect pricing but don't determine market size

components.text: % of craft beer that is IPA vs other styles
components.explanation: Beer style preference is too detailed
Alcohol content doesn't drive spending patterns
Store count doesn't determine consumer demand

explanation: To size the US craft beer market, start with beer drinkers who specifically choose craft over mass market options, then multiply by their average annual craft beer spending

prompt: What's the annual revenue of ride-sharing services in Canada?

components.explanation: This focuses on cities where ride-sharing operates

components.text: % of urban population that uses ride-sharing apps
components.explanation: Not all urban residents use these services

components.text: Average rides per user per month
components.explanation: Heavy users drive most of the revenue
This converts ride volume into revenue
Traditional taxi licensing is a different market
Car ownership reduces demand but too indirect

components.text: % of rides during peak vs off-peak hours
components.explanation: Peak timing affects pricing but captured in average
Trip distance affects individual fares but not market size
Driver count is supply-side, not demand

explanation: To estimate Canada's ride-sharing market, focus on urban users who actually use these apps, calculate how often they ride monthly, then multiply by average fare per trip
